results.title: The House that Jack built and other fabulous fables
results.brief_description: Six delightful classic fables including “The House that Jack built” about the bag of malt, a rat a cat and much more. “Rumpelstiltskin”, the strange little man who offers to help the miller’s daughter for a terrible price. The Bremen Town musicians” who outsmart the evil robbers. “The Magic broom which helps Brenda Bunny save the house from thieves. “Henny Penny” who is convinced that the sky is falling. “Copycat dog”, a city dog who must learn how to live on a farm.

results.title: The House that dripped blood
results.creator_credit: Amicus Productions, Cinerama, Max J Rosenberg, Milton Subotsky and Peter Duffell
results.brief_description: Four short stories are linked by a police investigation into the dire circumstances in which occupants of a haunted house perish. A mystery writer inhabits the house in order to finish his latest novel, but is overtaken by the idea that his fictionalised killer really exists. In the second episode, a retired businessman becomes obsessed with a waxwork figure of a beautiful woman. Thirdly, a single father to a young girl, who keeps her mysteriously separated from society, falls victim to witchcraft. In the final episode a horror-film actor, seeking authenticity in his work, is given the cloak of a real vampire. These stories are wonderfully creepy and rely not so much on bloodshed, as on supernatural thrills and gruesome trajectories.

results.title: The House on the waterfall
results.brief_description: Acclaimed by the American institute of Architects as the best American building built in the last 125 years, Fallingwater, built by Frank Lloyd Wright has attracted since its construction in 1936 ongoing international accolades. The home built as a summer residence for a family was designed in direct response to it’s environment. The building is sited over a waterfall using mostly counter-levered platforms. The documentary extrapolates on the building method (with archival footage) and details with interviews the materials used and intellectual ideals that directed the external and interior functionalist aesthetics. The documentary observes the home throughout the seasons to illustrate the depth of the Lloyd Wright’s design and his consideration for a place to be lived in and shared with a changing environment. Narrated by Bingo O’Malley.

results.title: The House of science
results.brief_description: The Eameses were very sceptical of attempts to limit the definition of creativity to “art.” ‘The House of Science’ articulates a vision of the history of science as a human creative endeavour. Originally produced as a multi-screen introduction to the United States Science Exhibit at the Seattle World’s Fair in 1962, this single screen version shows the role of scientists, their work, and their laboratories. Animated prologued by Glen Fleck, music by Elmer Bernstein, narrated by Laurence Harvey.

results.title: The House of names
results.brief_description: John Smith is convinced that changing his name will change his life. After trying out hundreds of name combinations he sets off for the registry office. But choosing a new name is only the beginning. His journey takes him to the heart of bureaucracy, and what he finds is not only a new identity but a common soul. Cast includes Kym Gyngell, Samuel Johnson, Tom Stringer, Maureen Sherlock.

results.title: The House of mirth [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Three Rivers, Terence Davies and Olivia Stewart
results.brief_description: A detailed, passionate adaptation of Edith Wharton’s 1905 novel, “The House of Mirth” is Terence Davies’ finest film to date. Lily Bart (in an exquisite performance by “X-Files” star Gillian Anderson) is an intelligent, unconventional woman in her late 20s, torn between a constraining, rigid society and her own individuality. In order to remain a member of New York’s elite social circle, Lily realises she must marry a wealthy, respectable man. But finding someone who will nourish her intellect, appreciate her unconventionality and provide the funds is painstakingly difficult. The film’s most powerful scenes are those between Lily and the man she is evidently most attracted to, Lawrence Selden, who ironically is not wealthy enough to make him a suitable husband. With no job and dependent on her rich maiden aunt for a daily allowance, from whom she hopes to receive an inheritance, Lily mistakenly asks Gus Trenor for some assistance. This act of borrowing only leads to further complications, involving the cunning Mr. Rosedale, that entangle Lily and limit her options. “The House of Mirth” charts Lily’s progressive defeat and the suffering she endures as she loses her name and, concomitantly, social respect. Alone and ostracised, Lily’s finale is a monumental passage in the film. “The House of Mirth” is a tragic tale about a woman who tries desperately to both be true to her heart and play by society’s rules. But she can’t have both and ultimately ends up with nothing at all. New York upper class society is a character unto itself throughout his film - a conservative and rigid set of attitudes, sentiments, and values that have the power to do terrible evil. Stars Gillian Anderson, Dan Aykroyd, Anthony LaPaglia, Eric Stoltz, Eleanor Bron, Laura Linney.

results.title: The House of man. Part 1. Our changing environment
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and The Conservation Foundation
results.brief_description: A discussion of the rampant waste of natural resources in cities, woodlands, and farmlands, and of the pollution of rivers and the air. Compares the “progress” achieved thorugh wasteful methods, and through intelligent conservation techniques. Shows how intelligence can be channelled to plan for progress wisely.
